utterances: No.
In fact, if you hear our first EP that came out, I think, in 1995, you can hear there's a huge difference I sang.
And my accent is so much stronger back then.
(SOUNDBITE SONG, ""GET ENOUGH"")
(Singing) I can be a monster if I want to be one.
But he's got me beaten by a landslide.
He's just crazy.
My kids it's interesting because they're friends will say, ""Oh, your mom, when she speaks, she's weird.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
You know, like, ""Why does she have an accent."" And like, my kids are like, ""What are you talking about?
She doesn't have an accent.
And you - I mean, you never had any intention of becoming a singer or certainly not the lead singer of an Indie band.
No.
And I read that you actually didn't think much of your voice at all.
No, no. I mean, I love singing just like most little girls love singing, you know, by yourself, but, no. Music was always part of my life.
I've - my family owned a rock magazine, very influential in France.
And so I grew up around musicians, and I've spent a lot of time in rehearsal studios.
So music was always part of my life, but more as a fan and - or connoisseur, but not as the actual performer or songwriter.
I want to ask you about the new record, ""All Hours,"" because there's a - obviously, an electronic influence on this record.
Mm-hmm.
And some of your past work has been described as sounding like Burt Bacharach.
I mean, there's really sort of a diversity in the way that you guys have evolved as a band.
Mm-hmm.
But a lot of music on this record really seems to pay homage to British alternative acts from the 1980's.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
(Singing) A promise we made ourselves to never (unintelligible).
And (unintelligible) you'll never tell, tell me not to break down (unintelligible).
Yeah, that's definitely true.
Walker cited an example last year from Johnson's column in London's Daily Telegraph, in which he wrote that women in burqas reminded him of mailboxes.
All you could see is the eyes, right?
Well, I agree with that because you can't see their identity.
That caused a lot of fuss in this country because he said what he thought and what a lot of people thought as well but were scared to say their comments, you see?
Melva Steckles says Trump and Johnson share other traits that she doesn't like.
Steckles, who served as leader of the district council in nearby Richmondshire, says both are showmen who shoot from the hip.
With Trump on your side of the pond (laughter) and Boris over this side, I do worry a bit about the details that get into the nub of the issue.
Because Trump just seems to blast out - doesn't he?
- on his Twitter, and that's a bit Boris as well.
Both candidates back Brexit, but given the stakes the country faces, Steckles much prefers Hunt, who ran England's National Health Service before taking over foreign affairs.
I feel it's a safer pair of hands in the ways that the world is at the moment.
I'm not for all the razzmatazz, necessarily; I want somebody who can lead the party, unite the party back together and get on with the job.
During today's forum, Hunt came off like an earnest, well-prepared student, with lots of ideas for the future.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We could be the country that's home to the fourth industrial revolution - driverless cars, drones, artificial intelligence, nanotechnology - all these things that will set us up for the future.

Meanwhile, Johnson energized the crowd with his trademark humor, charisma and defiance, telling party members the country must stick to the new October 31 deadline to leave the EU, even if that means walking away with no withdrawal agreement.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We have to believe in ourselves.
We've had enough of defeatism and negativity from this government.
The British people are fed up with being told that they can't do X, Y or Z when we know perfectly well that we can.
I think that our...
(APPLAUSE)
In fact, until last year, Johnson was a member of that government.
Many of Johnson's critics see him as a political opportunist, think he only backed Brexit to position himself to become prime minister.
At today's forum, the host caught Johnson off guard with this question.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Can you give an example in your political life when you've set your own self-interest aside for the benefit of the country?
Well, it's a good question.
But I would - you know, I don't - obviously - embarrassing but true.
But...
Johnson struggled but eventually came up with an example of self-sacrifice - he said devoting himself to politics means it will take him much longer to finish writing a book on Shakespeare.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
And that means that that unjustly neglected author will...
(LAUGHTER)
...Will no longer, you know, get the treatment he deserves.
And British readers will suffer, to which the crowd laughed, just as Johnson intended.
Frank Langfitt, NPR News, Darlington, England.
(SOUNDBITE OF THE JAM'S ""MUSIC FOR THE LAST COUPLE"")

Then there are those small boutiques that don't have fancy marketing executives helping them through the economic downturn, you know, those quaint little stores, they may be full of candles and wind chimes, where you may wonder, even in good times, how in the world do they survive?
Well, we wondered the same thing, so we went out into our backyard to answer that question.
Here in Culver City, California, we found two boutiques that are pushing through the hard times.
You really have to keep an image up, so even when things are difficult, if it looks like things are difficult, then people are not going to buy.
So, it makes it even more difficult.
That's Renee Mosley, she's the owner of Freesia.
It's got a new-age vibe to it.
You smell a mix of lavender and citrus when you walk in.
Mosley sells an array of gifts and accessories and specializes in custom-scented body bars.
People don't want a shop.
They want an experience.
I think people want a place to connect, and so when they shop, they want an experience of feeling connected to something greater.
And they also want to feel - I think they want to feel good.
So part of what I did was look at, OK, how do I keep that going and keep reminding people about what that is.
She's had to do a lot of reminding.
Business is down at Freesia, though Renee says she thinks she's got what customers want.
People are going really be cautious about how they are spending their money, and if they're spending it, that it's different, it's unique, and I get a good value for it.
They also still are going to want something from, I think, a boutique because when you're buying a really nice gift, you know, some people are not going to want it to come from a big box store.
That is the same reason Cathy(ph) Lundeen opened her shop just three months ago.
It's called Lundeen's and having Cathy's name on the door is very appropriate.
